results.title: The Snowy Mountains
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Ted Egan takes up the Snowy Mountains story 100 years after Australia’s favourite poet, Banjo Paterson, immortalised a young mountain horseman in his epic poem, “The Man From Snowy River”. Features the pioneering development and the lifestyle of the mountain’s people, including the historic construction of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme. Filmed over the four seasons, the story also includes an aerial kaleidoscope of the high country from spring to winter with spectacular displays of wild flowers and fragile alpine wilderness.

results.title: Left brain, right brain (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: John Bassett and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
This program examines the functions of the two halves of the human brain and current research being carried out by Canadian and American medical scientists. In addition to research into the nature of the split brain to find out what it controls before operating on it, we also see how different educational techniques in primitive and sophisticated societies may favour development of one hemisphere over the other. Presented and narrated by David Suzuki.

results.title: Storm clouds over the colonies
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
Tracing the history of the economic development of colonial territories, this film points out the shift in emphasis from the primary motives of discovery and the transfer of luxury goods to the establishment of permanent industries. The benefits of modern developments are weighed against exploitation, of which colonialism is never free. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Vision of Galileo
results.creator_credit: Italo Costa and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Visits the cities in which Galileo lived and worked: Pisa, Florence, Padua, Venice and Rome. Also repeats some of his experiments and explains them in a script based largely on Galileo’s own writings. With David Suzuki. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: They called it white man's burden
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”
Paternalism, with all its problems and achievements among colonial peoples, has a tradition within the Commonwealth which is often misunderstood. This film suggests that the stereotyped picture many people have of colonial officialdom needs revising in the light of Britain’s record. The “Great White Father,” we see, although not oblivious to the material advantages a colony could provide, brought with him, more often than not, a deep sense of responsibility for the welfare of people under his jurisdiction. Noteworthy are campaigns to improve agriculture, alleviate suffering, raise living standards and promote literacy.

results.title: The Jerusalem passion
results.brief_description: Recorded live in the Concert Hall of the Queensland Performing Arts Complex on 9th April 1988. “The Jerusalem passion” was composed and conducted by Christian music director, Murray Wylie and features the Vision One Choir and Orchestra, supported by vocalists Sue Elliott, Jeff Baldock, David Hall, Helen Maguire, Jim McCrystal, Damien Roche, Julie Vidler and Kate Wylie. Playing the pipe organ is Eduarda Van Klinken and the oratorio is narrated by Helen Foster. Vision One is an Australia-wide Christian music initiative.

results.title: A Pain in the back
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
A documentary about the causes of back pain in humans and the ways that different people cope with it. The methods, used for the treatment of back pain, that are looked at in the program are exercise, acupuncture and surgical intervention.

results.title: Out of the mouths of babes
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Focuses on Peter and Jill de Villiers, two Harvard researchers, and their contention that knowledge of a language is innate in humans and develops as the child matures biologically. Includes interviews with both scientists and highlights their work. Suitable for tertiary/teacher level.
